Articles.Content:
Right now the mk1 crew cabin seats its passengers on one side of the cabin and this causes it to give my craft an uneven weight distribution and a an off-center center of mass. It is significant enough that it prevents me from launching spacecraft with the mk1 crew cabin because they always tip over on the side where the passengers are sitting. It's very annoying.

 

I discovered this after troubleshooting for the last 3 hours to isolate the cause of my spacecraft's lack of balance. To replicate for yourself, just make a small, simple, perfectly symmetrical craft with the mk1 crew cabin and passengers inside it. In my tests I've discovered that apparently the seats themselves are light enough that they don't really make a difference, it only becomes a big problem when there are passengers.

 

Please, please, make the seats in the cabin in the center of the part. Or put the two seats on opposite sides.

Edited December 27, 2015 by imadeanaccountjusttosaythi

Ok, I'll bite.

 

Firstly, kerbals INSIDE a craft don't add any mass (unless something has changed). Secondly, just to see for myself before posting that first part, I built a craft consisting of a stayputnik, Mk1 cabin, a flea, two radial mount parachutes (because the IVA looking out the window looked so fun I wanted my kerbals to live) and two of the smallest fins (only because I couldn't stop it from flipping on its back due to aero) and launched from a single launch clamp at about a 60-70 degree angle. With/without kerbals it always flew in a straight line.
Yeah, I'm gonna go ahead and say you need to build a better plane.  This request makes no sense.  Nothing, and I do mean NOTHING in an IVA view affects the plane's performance.
You failed somewhere else. KSP does not simulate kerbal weight distribution INSIDE parts.
Is there maybe a plugin or something that he could have installed that does this?
Alright I believe you all. I have no idea how to explain my observations, but I believe you all.
Thread punted to Gameplay Discussion

You've probably got something outside that wasn't perfectly mirrored in symmetry. Happens all the time, unfortunately.

Best,

-Slashy
